faq.title: Common Questions
faq.subtitle: Here are answers to what you might be wondering.

items.question: Does the child pay for school essentials too?
items.answer: No. "Essential expenses" like uniforms and school-required items are covered by parents. Kids only manage "discretionary spending" from their allowance—things like casual clothes, stationery, hobbies, snacks, and friend activities. For anything unclear, decide together in advance.

items.question: What if they run out of money?
items.answer: No emotional top-ups. Instead, they choose from pre-agreed recovery options: earn through family gigs, borrow from next year's allowance, or give up interest. Essential needs are always covered by parents, so life won't fall apart.

items.question: Isn't it harsh if they fail?
items.answer: In this system, running out isn't a failure to avoid—it's a designed learning moment. Instead of blame, you discuss what to do next. Mistakes become material for growth, not punishment.

items.question: Won't parents over-monitor?
items.answer: Parents act as "rule designers and auditors," not surveillance. You don't micromanage daily choices—just review together once a month. Visibility isn't for control; it's for conversation.

items.question: Does this bribe kids with money for chores?
items.answer: Daily chores (cleaning, laundry, etc.) don't earn money. Family gigs only pay when there's a clear outcome and value delivered. The goal isn't the money—it's understanding the link between value and reward.

items.question: Is the amount normal compared to other families?
items.answer: We don't compare across families. The allowance depends on your values and situation. What matters isn't the number—it's building better judgment over time.
